lines: You are a guest at your friend Billy's house. His mom gives you both a box of crayons and two pieces of paper.
You are behaving yourself very nicely so far. You draw a pretty picture.
A very strong sign of developing social etiquette. Emily Post would certainly approve.
A very nice gesture. You can have a good time at somebody else's house for a short while, but there's no place like home.
You draw large circles and swirls with black crayon on the paper. Oops!  You drew on the expensive tablecloth.
Billy is a gracious host. He excuses you, then adds a stroke or two to your design (on the tablecloth, that is).
You casually slide the paper over the offending spot, where it will remain covered and undetected until after you leave. This was the sneaky, cowardly way out.
Your honesty is commendable. Billy's mom realizes she wasn't thinking clearly when she let you draw on top of the tablecloth. Will you be this honest when you get yourself into real trouble?
Probably not, but admitting this is a trustworthy sign in itself. You're all right.
You scribble back and forth wildly, creating bold slashes of color. When you are finished, you can:
Ah yes, the frustrated artist. Your impulsiveness combined with your desire for perfection keeps you in a state of "artistic turmoil."
You appreciate the value of even this kind of emotional expression. When you are famous, this scribbling might be worth a fortune.
You and Billy work each other into a frenzy (as little boys often do). First you cover the paper, then Billy suggests you redecorate the kitchen.

You and Billy create a fabulous mural on the kitchen wall, a real one-of-a-kind masterpiece. Unfortunately Billy's mom shares neither your enthusiasm, nor your love for the arts. You are sent home pronto and the last you saw of Billy, he
was being put into solitary confinement and holding a pillow on his rear end.

A valiant choice with an unfortunate outcome. When Billy's mother discovers his masterpiece she gives you joint credit. She does not know that you are definitely an impressionist while Billy is an obvious cubist. Adults!
